intro: Allium subhirsutum subsp. obtusitepalum, commonly known as the broad-leafed garlic, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It features a basal rosette of broad, fleshy, and often hairy leaves that are typically bluish-green in color. The plant produces upright, slender flowering stems that bear umbels of small, white or pale pink flowers. It is closely related to other Allium species and is valued for its aromatic leaves and potential culinary uses. This subspecies is characterized by its obtuse, rounded leaf tips, distinguishing it from other members of the species.
